comments.commentBody: The story doesn't end with this sad, tragic event of a chimp being placed in a world not its own. It only opens the door to a whole world in which we keep animals captive for our enjoyment. We may decry the keeping of primates as pets, but we think nothing of watching captive mammals -- orcas and dolphins -- being trained for our enjoyment. Ever wonder how they ended up in Sea World? One thing is certain: they did't chose it. These are intelligent, self aware animals that we essentially enslave for pleasure. Shame on humans, we know better yet we are indifferent to the suffering of other animals. We think we're so smart.

The comparison should be with A-Rod: what did Hank and Hal give A-Rod? That is, is A-Rod worth more than Jeter? Is A-Rod more VALUABLE than Jeter? Will A-Rod in his 40s be worth his contract? Jeter in his?

A-Rod's into-his-40s contract is the baseline for negotiation. And then, when you consider what they gave Clemens -- was it $22 million? I can't recall exactly -- then consider this:

Jeter gets 6 years at $150 million. and that's just the starting point.

I am not saying this is good or bad, just based on precedent.
I don't remember Andy Petitte perjuring himself in front of Congress. Just saying...

Excellent piece on these lunatics and the damage they do. My own family has had run-ins with so-called Christian missionaries of various descriptions in the past. When Sri Lanka (then Ceylon) was a British colony, some of these people (often from major churches and backed by their headquarters in the West) waged campaigns to forcibly convert locals from Buddhism and Hinduism to their own forms of Christianity. If they tried that now, the government of Sri Lanka would deport them on the next available flight out of Colombo.

In my travels across the world, I have met no group of people who collectively do so much harm as American Christian missionaries.

Jared Diamond tells the story of two villages in the highlands of New Guinea. One was thriving selling art for the tourist trade, the other had nothing. The former retained its nativist traditions, the latter had become Christianized. It's a story I've seen elsewhere. in Amazonia, in Indonesia, in West Africa, it's the Christian villages where native culture is destroyed.

Silsby suffers from the same sort of Christian entitlement complex we saw in Brit Hume when he urged Tiger Woods to become a Christian because Buddhism somehow wasn't good enough to save him. Her inclinations are part & parcel of the evangelical impulse to "save" Israel so American Christians can be Raptured up. According to Jacques Chirac, this Christianist theology was the basis for George Bush's invasion of Iraq, which he saw as fulfilling a prophecy from Ezekiel. This is the same hubris that led Justice Antonin Scalia to insist in court that a cross could honor a Jew or an atheist & non-Christians ought to be pleased to be so honored. It's the same impulse that leads seemingly sane politicians & others to end speeches with "God bless America," (thank you, Irving Berlin!) as if this country had an extra special place in the divine's heart. We are exceptional! And we are exceptionally Christian.

Rant on Silsby if you want, but it is a baby step, not a giant leap, from Silsby to Scalia to Bush. We are one scary-crazy nation of narcissistic, holier-than-thou, arrogant, anti-intellectual fundamentalists.

The Constant Weader at www.RealityChex.com

I think it is fair to say that the Vancouver games fiscal plans were made well before the onset of the current world recession, and that the capital expense side was not amenable to much economizing. It is likely that, under normal economic circumstances, ones in which sponsors such as GM did not go bankrupt, the financial outcome might have been less unfavorable. The financial shortcomings in planning for security, however, must serve as a signal warning to the organizers of any future games.

All the naysayers and the hand-wringers are back on board after this game.  I'm just glad Ovechkin got a stiff taste of his own medicine.  I know you're not supposed to look ahead, but what a final U.S.-Canada Part 2 would be.  Dare I imagine that NBC would show it on the main channel?

At first I was sitTINg pretty, but then I goT INto trouble, since the answers did not fiT INto the space, giving me a TINge of anguish, buT IN the end, everything worked.

Very clever puzzle. Once I figured it out I was expecting to see Tintin, the Belgian cartoon character: http://en.wikipedia.org...

It is written that Canada and the US will play in the finals.
The loser will adopt the health-care plan of the winner.
(Is there a better way to decide the debate?)

In Vancouver we have all loved the coverage of NBC. The heart warming stories of your athletes and other countries athletes, the warmth and knowledge of the commentators and the kindness they've shown to all Canadians.  Thank you to all.

Michael (Seattle Wa) is right. We don't really care about the US. The Russians are it. It's always with 1972 emotion when we play them. (You have to be over 50 to get the reference.)

As for you, USA, Miller will have a bad game sooner or later, and I suspect it will be soon, against us.

The 'marTINi' tipped me off, quickly resolving multiple "no room for my answer" dilemmas. After that it was mostly a matter of winkling out the other TIN spots. Except for TINSMITH and RIN TIN TIN (I vaguely remember that show as being much better than the one with that sissy Lassie) all of the TINs were buried in their words. Pretty tricky.

I always read _Old Yeller_ aloud to my students; Fred Gipson's book is MUCH better than the sappy movie.

Is [Scratch] as a clue for KALE supposed to be a reference to $$ ? I once heard something like 'leaves of cabbage' for bills (in "The Best Years of Their Lives") but kale?

Enjoyable puzzle that kept me on my toes. Don't I recall this Holden Baker as a newer constructor, seen recently?

"Aren't there more important things to write about and discuss?" #9 wants to know. Sure, #9, there's the ugliness of war, the ineptitude of politicians, the depressing state of the economy and a thousand other such inspirational subjects in queue. Why waste our precious time on the grace, power, and exuberance of female athletes doing wonderful things on ice skates!

The Russians have nothing to prove. They stunk it up tonight but they're still the team to beat in Sochi. As for gooning it up, I'd say Canada has done that so many times to the Soviets and then the Russians that a little payback must be nice.

Taking advantage of other's misery cannot be God's work.  We are seeing this type of behaviour time and again in many other places. In the shadow of US military tanks and helicopters these missionaries venturing into dangerous places and they are always saved by diplomatic clouts of America. As long as we are giving them the diplomatic cover they will be keep engaging themselves in this type of misadventures again and again. It is time that we stop making excuses for them and let them face the consequences of their actions.

C'mon Tim. Condemning looney fundamentalists? Like shooting fish in a barrel. OF COURSE it was idiocy. Now move on and tell the readers of the Times what they should do to help Haitians.

Tsk-tsking these people isn't going to do it. They and their ilk are not reading the Times.
The bubble will burst, the slooping shoulders will return, viewership/jersey sales will droop as long as D'Antoni is coach. He looks so spent.

Mean Old Elaine,

If you click on the Xword Info Solution link in the blog post, you get a lot of information on the puzzle and constructor:

http://www.xwordinfo.com...

It shows that this is Mr, Baker's (he goes by "Denny") fifteenth Times puzzle. If you click on his name, you can see the 14 others.

And yes, kale is cabbage, scatch or moolah.

Mosi Tatupu sustained a successful fourteen year N.F.L. career through toughness, durability, and versatility.

As a fullback and halfback Tatupu could run, catch, and was an excellent blocker, both as a lead back in the running game and picking up blitzes in pass protection. He was a strong, physical goal-line and short yardage runner.

Tatupu will probably be best remembered as an outstanding special teams player, one of the best of his era.

He particularly excelled on the kickoff coverage team. Here, coaches are looking for aggressive players who are big enough to take on double-teams and wedge blocks and fast enough to chase if the return is away. They must attack potential blockers and create collisions. They had better be sound tacklers and, most importantly, they must have the intense desire to be part of a successful unit. Mosi Tatupu possessed all these necessary qualities.

That kickoff coverage team played a vital role in New England's Super Bowl run in 1985. In the wild card game against the Jets, Johnny Rembert's 15 yard return of a fumbled kickoff broke the game open in the third quarter in a 26-14 win.

In the divisional playoff against the Raiders, the Patriots tied the game in the third quarter, 20-20, on a 32 yard field goal by Tony Franklin. On the ensuing kickoff Sam Seale fielded the ball on the nine yard line, fumbled it, picked it up, but fumbled again after Tatupu nailed him. The ball rolled into the end zone where it was covered by Jim Bowman for the touchdown that proved to be the winning margin.

The following week, in the A.F.C. Championship game against the Dolphins, Tatupu did it again. His hit on Lorenzo Hampton forced a fumble on the second half kickoff. The Patriots recovered on the Miami 25 and scored six plays later to extend their lead to 24-7 in an eventual 31-14 victory.

Mosi Tatupu played football with passion. He gave it everything he had on every play, in every role, with infectious enthusiasm, and without complaint. What more could a coach, or a fan, ask for?

This whole topic is such crap.  Leave the guy (and his wife) alone.  He's a young guy with megabucks and women were no doubt "throwing themselves" at him.  So none of this should be a surprise to any of us, including his wife.  After all, really, WHAT, repeat, WHAT has been lost by anyone.  Let him & his wife deal with it and leave him alone.

First, to R. West (# 1): You have no idea how many millions of women would love to trade places with you. So many marriages become virtually sexless, especially after the first child is born. You barely start to undress and your husband is turned on? Deal with it.
Secondly, could someone introduce me to one of these "sex addicts?" I would love to learn their seduction technique, so I could get laid once in a while.

"Money creates power. Power creates the ability to become corrupt and go against our societies [sic] beliefs...and allows [humans] to do the things that most [humans] only dream about in their fantasies."

hmmm, so this implies that we all have the potential to become sex addicts, but most of us just lack the means.

since money creates power, and power corrupts, is that why the rest of us are so concerned about economic equality? We want to live in a non-corrupt society? If we tax Mr. Woods' wealth prohibitively, maybe then he couldn't become "corrupt". He would be randy just like the rest of us, but lack the means to excessively fulfill his desires.

Other points:
1) men and women are both corruptible, so let's keep the text gender neutral.
2) please do not generalize your beliefs about "fidelity" to all of society. The goodness of fidelity marriage and monogamy are your beliefs, and you should not generalize your beliefs to the rest of us.
3) what are YOUR fantasies? If you had Mr. Woods' wealth and fame, what would want to do?
4) what are YOUR current addictions, assuming that you currently lack Mr. Woods' wealth and fame? alcohol? nicotine? methamphetamines? work? money? food? caffeine? amphetamines? gambling? i am not sure that Mr. Woods has an exceptionally news-worthy or notable addiction. i would rather be addicted to sex than some other things.
here in England there are sportsman who are being found out to be cheating quite often. It is fair to say that they have been caught cheating, and IS an excuse to say it is an addiction!. Andy
My girldfriend and I stayed in Fortuna city. We look for a cheap B&B and found Rabfer hotel. They have a nice and clean rooms. Very cheap. Ask for Roselia, the owner. www.arenalrabfer.com
